snippet: While bond purchases pushed down borrowing costs and helped Spain and Italy avoid a Greek-style bailout from the euro zone, they once again have enmeshed the banks in their debt woes.
abstract: Spain and Italy are considered the two countries in the euro zone most susceptible to a second round of financial problems amid signs that banks in those nations are once again loading up on the sovereign debt of their governments; bond purchases pushed down borrowing costs, helping Spain and Italy avoid Greek-style bailouts, but new risks have been raised by tying the health of the banks to the fate of their governments.
lead_paragraph: While bond purchases pushed down borrowing costs and helped Spain and Italy avoid a Greek-style bailout from the euro zone, they once again have enmeshed the banks in their debt woes.

headline.seo: Spanish and Italian Banks, Once More Buying Bonds, Seen as Vulnerable
headline.main: In Europe, Unease Over Bank Debt
headline.print_headline: In Europe, Unease Over Bank Debt
